Award.AwardTitle: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Scalable Kinship Inference in Wild Populations Across Years and Generations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scalable kinship inference in wild populations across years and generations

A cornerstone of research in molecular ecology is the reconstruction of family groups (kinship analysis).
Understanding how individuals in free-living populations are related to each other provides the best
opportunity to study many important biological processes, ranging from sexual selection to patterns
of dispersal and recruitment. Recent advances in molecular DNA technologies and computational
methods have made these studies possible. However, many conceptual and computational challenges
remain and need to be addressed in order to advance these studies. To date, existing research work
on kinship analysis has primarily focused on computational methods that address a single relationship, such as parentage assignment or reconstruction of full sib groups. Inclusion of multiple objectives, such as half-sib reconstruction with minimum parentage assignment, or hierarchy over multiple generations, makes formulation of the underlying computational problem extremely challenging, and simple extensions of previous methods do not address in a practical, scalable, and robust manner the problem of kinship reconstruction for data sets that include multiple generations of species or involve multiple optimization functions.

The goal of the proposed research is to design robust, parsimonious, and versatile computational
approaches for inferring multi-generation kinship relationships in wild populations from multiallelic
markers. Parsimony assumption is fundamental to these approaches as it requires no prior knowledge,
assumptions about sampling methodology, or existence of models, which is the case for most free-living
populations. The diverse tasks of this project include formulating computational kinship inference
problems based on existing biological studies, analyzing computational complexity of and providing
solutions to the resulting combinatorial optimization problems, and designing robust, scalable and
efficient high performance implementations. The resulting computational methods will be evaluated
on datasets collected from existing biological studies and will be deployed to the biological community
through the Kinalyzer web-based service, currently actively used for sibship inference only.

The research proposed in this project will greatly impact diverse application areas including funda-
mental research in combinatorial optimization and data mining, and within biology, areas as diverse as
behavioral ecology, evolutionary genetics, conservation, forensics, and epidemiology. The multidisci-
plinary nature of the project and the research team will enhance curriculum design of related areas and
introduce new cross-disciplinary courses. This cohesive, multidisciplinary project will provide training
opportunities in biology, operation research, algorithms analysis, bioinformatics and high performance
computing, within a single application framework. The project will leverage the diverse scientific ex-
pertise and extensive mentoring experience of the team to foster a true interdisciplinary collaboration
and to provide a thriving environment for a new generation of interdisciplinary scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A cornerstone of research in molecular ecology is the reconstruction of family groups (kinship analysis). Understanding how individuals in free-living populations are related to each other provides the best opportunity to study many important biological processes, ranging from sexual selection to patterns of dispersal and recruitment. Recent advances in molecular DNA technologies and computational methods have made these studies possible. However, many conceptual and computational challenges remain and need to be addressed in order to advance these studies. To date, existing research work on kinship analysis, including ours, has primarily focused on computational methods that address a single relationship, such as parentage assignment or reconstruction of full sibling groups. Inclusion of multiple objectives, such as half-sib reconstruction with minimum parentage assignment, or hierarchy over multiple generations, makes formulation of the underlying computational problem extremely challenging, and simple extensions of previous methods do not address in a practical, scalable, and robust manner the problem of kinship reconstruction for data sets that include multiple generations of species or involve multiple optimization functions. 

In this project, we have developed algorithms and computational tools for inferring non-trivial kinship relationships from genetic data. We surveyed existing biological studies that use kinship inference to understand the types of available data, the inferred relationships of interest, and the biological constraints. We formalized these biological problems into computational optimization problems and analyzed their computational complexity, that is, the efficiency of the algorithms to solve these problems.

Many of the kinship inference problems fall into the class of the computationally intractable, known as NP-complete, problems. To solve even relatively small instances of such problems with the best-known algorithms requires impractically large amount of time. One of the possible approaches to speed up the algorithms is to use the highly parallelized processing architecture, Graphics Processing Unit (GPU). Most of the kinship inference problems can be formulated as Integer Linear Programs (ILPs), which requires repeating matrix-vector multiplication of sparse integer matrices. We have designed a special data structure for sparse integer matrices for GPU processing, called AdELLE, and used it to speed up vector-vector and matrix-vector multiplication in general, as well as kinship ILPs in particular.

We have deployed our tools as a web-based application, freely available to anybody, at kinalyzer.cs.uic.edu (Fig 1). More than 100,000 kinship inference requests from scientists all over the world have been fulfilled by Kinalyzer since it went live in 2009.

More than ten graduate students in biology and computer science have worked on research projects that stemmed out of the work supported directly or indirectly by this grant. Many collaborations have been born. The biological motivation and the computational abstractions of the problems from this project have been used in computer science courses, from a newly designed introductory computer science course based completely on biological context, to an advanced graduate-level course on algorithms in computational biology. The attractive application to animal biology served as a great introduction to computer science in countless talks delivered by the PI to wider public, from elementary and middle school audiences to wildlife biologists.

In summary, impacts of this research span computer science, biology, and education. It has enabled basic biological sciences, advanced the development of fast computational paradigms, and inspired some to continue a career in computer science.

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2018
Modified by: Tanya Berger-Wolf

    Kinalyzer
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A cornerstone of research in molecular ecology is the reconstruction of family groups (kinship analysis). Understanding how individuals in free-living populations are related to each other provides the best opportunity to study many important biological processes, ranging from sexual selection to patterns of dispersal and recruitment. Recent advances in molecular DNA technologies and computational methods have made these studies possible. However, many conceptual and computational challenges remain and need to be addressed in order to advance these studies. To date, existing research work on kinship analysis, including ours, has primarily focused on computational methods that address a single relationship, such as parentage assignment or reconstruction of full sibling groups. Inclusion of multiple objectives, such as half-sib reconstruction with minimum parentage assignment, or hierarchy over multiple generations, makes formulation of the underlying computational problem extremely challenging, and simple extensions of previous methods do not address in a practical, scalable, and robust manner the problem of kinship reconstruction for data sets that include multiple generations of species or involve multiple optimization functions. In this project, we have developed algorithms and computational tools for inferring non-trivial kinship relationships from genetic data. We surveyed existing biological studies that use kinship inference to understand the types of available data, the inferred relationships of interest, and the biological constraints. We formalized these biological problems into computational optimization problems and analyzed their computational complexity, that is, the efficiency of the algorithms to solve these problems. Many of the kinship inference problems fall into the class of the computationally intractable, known as NP-complete, problems. To solve even relatively small instances of such problems with the best-known algorithms requires impractically large amount of time. One of the possible approaches to speed up the algorithms is to use the highly parallelized processing architecture, Graphics Processing Unit (GPU). Most of the kinship inference problems can be formulated as Integer Linear Programs (ILPs), which requires repeating matrix-vector multiplication of sparse integer matrices. We have designed a special data structure for sparse integer matrices for GPU processing, called AdELLE, and used it to speed up vector-vector and matrix-vector multiplication in general, as well as kinship ILPs in particular. We have deployed our tools as a web-based application, freely available to anybody, at kinalyzer.cs.uic.edu (Fig 1). More than 100,000 kinship inference requests from scientists all over the world have been fulfilled by Kinalyzer since it went live in 2009. More than ten graduate students in biology and computer science have worked on research projects that stemmed out of the work supported directly or indirectly by this grant. Many collaborations have been born. The biological motivation and the computational abstractions of the problems from this project have been used in computer science courses, from a newly designed introductory computer science course based completely on biological context, to an advanced graduate-level course on algorithms in computational biology. The attractive application to animal biology served as a great introduction to computer science in countless talks delivered by the PI to wider public, from elementary and middle school audiences to wildlife biologists. In summary, impacts of this research span computer science, biology, and education. It has enabled basic biological sciences, advanced the development of fast computational paradigms, and inspired some to continue a career in computer science.
